description: From Middle English gropien, from Old English grāpian, related to grīpan (whence English gripe); compare also grip.

entries.meaning: (informal) An act of groping, especially sexually.
examples: The old man tried to get a quick grope of the young lady on the train.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An iron fitting of a medieval cart wheel.

verbs.description: grope (third-person singular simple present gropes, present participle groping, simple past and past participle groped)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To feel with or use the hands; to handle.

To search or attempt to find something in the dark, or, as a blind person, by feeling; to move about hesitatingly, as in darkness or obscurity; to feel one's way, as with the hands, when one can not see.
examples: to grope about a little longer among the miseries and sensualities of a worldly life

entries.meaning: To touch (another person) closely and (especially) sexually.
examples: The parents found the couple kissing and groping.

entries.meaning: To intentionally and inappropriately touch or rub against another person, in such a manner as to make the contact appear accidental, for the purpose of one's sexual gratification.
examples: That old man groped that girl on the train!

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To examine; to test; to sound.
examples: Felix gropeth him, thinking to have a bribe.
